title: Avatological standout
content:
Ah, the science of selecting a public face. So, why did you choose your avatar (or opt not to)?

Please tell me to mind my own business if you like but I'm genuinely interested in how your mind works...

Mine's fairly self-explanatory (incuding the lacklustre typography!) but some aren't. For example, why are some smaller than the suggested size?

I'm really intrigued by some avatars...
author: Nick Job

but it's probably worth asking again (especially as some answering the first time have changed since then).

My icon is from a photo of an artifact known as the ["Mask of Agamemnon"](http://web.archive.org/web/20150421234942/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mask_of_Agamemnon). [Agamemnon](http://web.archive.org/web/20150421234942/http:/typophile.com/node/41105) is also the working title of a multilingual font I have been working on for a very long time now.

Mine is my name written in the nastaliq style of Arabic script. The original graphic was sent to me by a fellow Typophile, in gratitude for some assistance I had provided, and was written by his calligrapher friend. It is one of the nicest things anyone has ever given me.

Mine is the logo of the [Bureau for Paranormal Research and Defense](http://web.archive.org/web/20150421234942/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bureau_for_Paranormal_Research_and_Defense) - Can't recall why I picked it, it's probably due for a change.

Here's a t-shirt with the logo (worn by Scud in Blade II) - [http://www.fanzone50.com/Norman/Scud\_82.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150421234942/http:/www.fanzone50.com/Norman/Scud_82.jpg "http://www.fanzone50.com/Norman/Scud\_82.jpg")

Mine is a monogram/signet that I have been using as my logo for 16 years or so. It owes some small debt of inspiration to Albrecht Dürer. And if I remember correctly, I originally derived the letterforms from Carol Twombly’s Charlemagne.

I’ve been thinking it’s due for an upgrade.

I use mine as my logo too. It's an 'e' I designed for a sign years ago, and I like it because it was my first go at lettering. The inspiration came from an album cover with cool lettering: [Spooky's Gargantuan](http://web.archive.org/web/20150421234942/http:/misssssskind.no.sapo.pt/dbimg/SpookyGargantuan199631736_f.jpg).

I remember I wanted a symmetrical 'e' and it was a breakthrough when I realised I could centre the stem. I like the way it looks like some kind of alien scarab. Sometimes I change the colours.

I lazily reused the one I made for my online hockey-pool.  
I had been planning on designing a fancy monogram, but decided to stop procrastinating and just sign up already.

Mine is the sequence U+0078 Latin Small Letter X U+0331 Combining Macron Below in Victor Gaultney’s Gentium Italic. It’s a key letter in the popular orthography of the Tlingit language, representing the uvular fricative, IPA /χ/. When combined with U+02BC Modifer Letter Apostrophe it symbolises the ejective uvular fricative, IPA /χʼ/. This latter sound occurs in no other known language except Tlingit, and it happens to be the first sound in the words for _x̱ʼé_ “mouth”, _yóo x̱ʼatángi_ “language”, _x̱ʼatoowú_ “meaning”, _x̱ʼala.átk_ “discourse”, and other similar ideas.

The proper typographic support for U+0331 Combining Macron Below is a personal campaign of mine, coming from its extensive use in Tlingit as well as in several other orthographies for indigenous languages of the Pacific Northwest of North America. Not having the diacritic in a typeface is one thing, but there’s a surprising number of fonts out there which have the diacritic but don’t actually support its use on anything, or only support it on the precomposed characters specified in Unicode and not on anything else. Notice how the diacritic is visually aligned with the center of the italic X, how it’s approximately the same width as the left-to-right stroke, and how it’s positioned just a bit more than one stroke width from the bottom of the X.

Another reason for this avatar is because I really love Victor Gaultney’s Gentium and I’m patiently waiting for a new release of the full font...
